caption: In the United States, Amazon often boxes orders at its warehouses, then hands the package off to a carrier such as the United Parcel Service for delivery. In India, with endemic traffic snarl, incomplete roadways and vague street addresses, delivering packages is far more challenging. Those conditions have forced Amazon to come up with new approaches to getting customers their goods.
Amazon’s 20 Indian warehouses are a fraction of the size of its warehouses in other countries, in part, because the company needs to spread goods around cities to ensure speedy delivery.

Inside the warehouses, items are picked and packed by Amazon workers. Most are then delivered by Amazon trucks to distribution centers, small buildings within India’s cities. Amazon says it has more than 170 distribution centers in India.
After those packages are sorted, they take one of two paths...
Some packages are delivered in a bundle to neighborhood stores. There, customers can either pick up their order, or store employees can deliver the parcels directly to customers.
The other packages are stuffed into large backpacks, which are handed off to motorcycle delivery drivers. Those drivers then deliver each parcel to Amazon customers.
